## THE PROBLEM: REACTIVE POLICING

<div class="glass-box" style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
SEPTA carries thousands of passengers daily. But for Transit Police, a critical question remains unanswered:

<div style="font-size: 1.2em; margin-top: 15px; padding-left: 20px; border-left: 4px solid #e0e0e0;">
**Does high ridership bring safety (<span class="text-blue">"Eyes on the Street"</span>) or does it attract crime (<span class="text-pop">"Potential Targets"</span>)?**
</div>
</div>

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
<div class="glass-box" style="height: 90%;">
<h3 style="color: #6baed6; border-bottom: none;">üö´ CURRENT ISSUES</h3>

1. **Inefficiency:** Patrols wasted on safe, high-traffic stops.
2. **Safety Gaps:** Missed anomalies where risk is high despite low visibility.
3. **Resource Strain:** The "Shotgun approach" fails with limited personnel.
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
<div class="glass-box" style="height: 90%">
<h3 style="color: #de2d26; border-bottom: none;">üö® Our Policy Goal</h3>

- Help SEPTA Transit Police transition from **reactive** to **predictive** deployment. 

- We identify <span class="text-pop">"High-Risk Anomalies"</span>‚Äîstops where environmental context and timing converge to create danger.
</div>
:::

:::

## Why Not Linear Regression?

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}
<div class="img-card" style="margin-top: 20px;">
![](Distribution.png)
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

<div style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.1); padding: 25px; border-radius: 15px; border-left: 6px solid #4fc3f7; margin-top: 20px;">
  
  <h3 style="color: #ffffff; margin-top: 0; font-size: 1.1em; border-bottom: none; font-weight: 800; text-transform: uppercase;">
    The Statistical Reality
  </h3>

  <ul style="font-size: 0.9em; margin-bottom: 0; margin-left: 20px; color: #e0e0e0; line-height: 1.5;">
    <li style="margin-bottom: 15px;">
      <span style="color: white; font-weight: bold;">The Nature:</span> 
      Crime data is a discrete <strong>Count Variable</strong> (0, 1, 2...).
    </li>
    <li style="margin-bottom: 15px;">
      <span style="color: white; font-weight: bold;">The Problem:</span> 
      It is heavily <span class="text-pop">Right-Skewed</span>. Most stops have zero crime, creating "Overdispersion" (Variance >> Mean).
    </li>
    <li>
      <span style="color: white; font-weight: bold;">The Solution:</span> 
      We used <strong>Negative Binomial Regression</strong> instead of OLS to mathematically account for this distribution.
    </li>
  </ul>

</div>

:::

:::

## The Core Hypothesis: Guardian or Target?

### Unmasking the Dual Nature of Ridership

We suspect ridership plays **competing roles** in public safety. A simple regression averages these effects, potentially hiding the truth.

<div style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.05); padding: 20px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 25px 0; border-left: 5px solid #ffc107;">
**Method:** Split the data into Weekdays and Weekends, and use the interaction term to <span class="text-pop">isolate</span> the impact of Ridership.
</div>

* <span class="text-blue">**Scenario A (Eyes on the Street):**</span> 
  Commuters create natural surveillance.
  * *Expectation:* Higher ridership $\rightarrow$ **Less** Crime.
  
* <span class="text-pop">**Scenario B (Potential Targets):**</span> 
  Leisure crowds create opportunities for theft.
  * *Expectation:* Higher ridership $\rightarrow$ **More** Crime.

**The Model Specification:**

$$Crime = \beta_0 + \underbrace{\beta_1(Ridership)}_{\text{Guardian Effect}} + \beta_2(Weekend) + \underbrace{\mathbf{\beta_3(Ridership \times Weekend)}}_{\text{Target Effect (The Shift)}}$$

## Model Validation (CV Results)

**Model Performance Improves with Each Layer**

| Model | MAE (Error Count) | RMSE | Improvement |
|-------|:-----------------:|:----:|:-----------:|
| 1. Ridership Only | 17.268 | 28.877 | - |
| 2. + Interaction | 17.209 | 28.868 | + 0.3% |
| 3. + Env & Demo | 12.777 | 21.039 | + 26% |
| 4. + Fixed | 11.409 | 18.343 | + 33.9% |
| 5. + Temporal Lag | 7.453 | 11.629 | + 56.8% |
| 6. Refined | 7.475 | 11.662 | + 56.7% |

::: {.callout-tip}
## Conclusion
**Context Matters.** Adding environmental variables and temporal lags reduced prediction error by **56.7%**.
:::

## LIMITATIONS & EQUITY

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
<div class="glass-box" style="height: 95%;">
  <h3 style="color: #ffc107; margin-top: 0; font-size: 1.2em; border-bottom: none;">
    ‚ö†Ô∏è MODEL LIMITATIONS
  </h3>
  
  <ul style="font-size: 0.9em; line-height: 1.6; margin-top: 20px;">
    <li style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
      <strong>Unobserved Variables:</strong><br>
      The model cannot capture real-time shocks like temporary <span class="text-pop">gang activity</span> or large events (e.g., concerts).
    </li>
    <li>
      <strong>Spatial Lag:</strong><br>
      Crime is fluid. Our 400m buffer is static, potentially missing cross-boundary crime displacement or spillover effects.
    </li>
  </ul>
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
<div class="glass-box" style="height: 95%;">
  <h3 style="color: #de2d26; margin-top: 0; font-size: 1.2em; border-bottom: none;">
    ‚öñÔ∏è ALGORITHMIC BIAS
  </h3>
  
  <ul style="font-size: 0.9em; line-height: 1.6; margin-top: 20px;">
    <li style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
      <strong>The Risk (Over-Policing):</strong><br>
      Reliance on <em>Poverty Rate</em> or <em>Vacancy</em> creates a feedback loop, targeting low-income neighborhoods even when no crime occurs.
    </li>
    <li>
      <strong>The Evidence (Blue Zones):</strong><br>
      Our Residual Analysis confirmed this: The model <span class="text-blue">Over-Predicted</span> risk in specific low-income areas, flagging them as dangerous when they were actually safe.
    </li>
  </ul>
</div>
:::

:::
